name: Vintage Gogatsu Ningyou Warrior Helmet #2
description:
Background: In Japan, the traditional Tango-no-Sekku Festival is held in May to wish for boys’ healthy growth. Families with boys celebrate this day by displaying the Gogatsu Ningyo (warrior doll) display reproduced as art objects, which were once worn by brave warriors. This tradition originated during the Heian Period more than 1200 years ago to ward off evil spirits. Later in the feudal era, this ritual evolved into a ceremony to pray for boys’ fortune and success in wars, and then gradually spread among the common people as a festival for children.

Dimensions (helmet): 
W32mcm x D22cm x H27cm (3000 gram)

Material: steel

name: Traditional Japanese Ukiyoe-style Kites #2
description:
Background: Ukiyo-e is a genre of Japanese woodblock prints (or woodcuts) and paintings produced between the 17th and the 20th centuries, featuring motifs of landscapes, tales from history, the theatre, and pleasure quarters. It is the main artistic genre of woodblock printing in Japan.

Usually the word ukiyo is literally translated as "floating world" in English, referring to a conception of an evanescent world, impermanent, fleeting beauty and a realm of entertainments (kabuki, courtesans, geisha) divorced from the responsibilities of the mundane, everyday world; "pictures of the floating world", i.e. ukiyo-e, are considered a genre unto themselves.

Choose from 4 traditional Japanese designs.

size: 44cm x 37cm
material: paper, wood

name: Traditional Japanese Ukiyoe-style Kites #1

Choose from 6 traditional Japanese designs including Mt. Fuji and Kabuki actors.

name: Japanese Kamon Coasters (Set of 4)
description:
Background: Mon, also monshō, mondokoro, and kamon, are Japanese emblems used to decorate and identify an individual or family.

Mon may have originated as fabric patterns to be used on clothes in order to distinguish individuals or signify membership in a specific clan or organization.

Like European heraldry, mon were initially held only by aristocratic families, and were gradually adapted by commoners. On the battlefield, mon served as army standards, even though this usage was not universal and uniquely designed army standards were just as common as mon-based standards.

size: appr. 11cm x 11cm
material: coton
select any 4 kamon coasters from photos

name: Elegant Washi Purse #2
description:
Ladies Purse/Wallet made from Japanese Washi Paper

Background: Washi is a style of paper that was first made in Japan. Washi is commonly made using fibers from the bark of the gampi tree, the mitsumata shrub, or the paper mulberry, but also can be made using bamboo, hemp, rice, and wheat. Washi comes from wa meaning Japanese and shi meaning paper, and the term is used to describe paper made by hand in the traditional manner.

Washi is generally tougher than ordinary paper made from wood pulp, and is used in many traditional arts. Origami, Shodo, and Ukiyo-e were all produced using washi. Washi was also used to make various everyday goods like clothes, household goods, and toys as well as vestments and ritual objects for Shinto priests and statues of Buddha. It was even used to make wreaths that were given to winners in the 1998 Winter Paralympics. 

width: 18.3cm
height: 10.5cm
thickness: 2cm
weight: 60gram
material: washi

name: Elegant Washi Purse #1
description:

Washi comes from wa meaning Japanese and shi meaning paper, and the term is used to describe paper made by hand in the traditional manner.

Washi is generally tougher than ordinary paper made from wood pulp, and is used in many traditional arts. Origami, Shodo, and Ukiyo-e were all produced using washi. name: Oyako Shingata Kokeshi
description:
Vintage Japanese Wooden Doll

Background: Oyako, in Japanese means "parent and child", in this case a mother and her child. 

"Traditional" kokeshi (dentō-kokeshi) dolls' shapes and patterns are particular to a certain area and are classified under eleven types. "Creative" kokeshi (shingata-kokeshi) allow the artist complete freedom in terms of shape, design and color and were developed after World War II (1945). They are not particular to a specific region of Japan and generally creative kokeshi artists are found in cities.

The woods used for kokeshi vary, with cherry used for its darkness and dogwood for its softer qualities. Itaya-kaede, a Japanese maple, is also used in the creation of both traditional and creative dolls. This vintage kokeshi is made of several kinds of wood including the ones mentioned above.

Dimensions:
Mother Kokeshi height: 24cm tall (waist: 37.5cm), weight:1150gram
Child Kokeshi height: 16cm tall, weight: 600gram

name: Gogatsu-Ningyo Samurai Armor Set incl. Yoroi and Kabuto #9
description:
Gogatsu-Ningyo Samurai Armor Set incl. Yoroi and Kabuto

Background: In the Edo period (1603-1867), people used to display a set of helmet and armor, weapons and banners outdoors on the 'Tango-no-Sekku' Festival which marks the beginning of summer or the rainy season. Tan means "edge" or "first" and go means "noon". 

Nowadays Gogatsu-Ningyo (doll warrior) are usually displayed on May 5 which has become 'Kodomo no Hi' or Children's day. In contrast to the Hina Festival on March 3 which was and remains an occasion to wish for a girl's safe passage into adulthood, this festival has been developed into an event to wish for a boy's strong growth and bravery.

This handmade Gogatsu Ningyo includes a 'kabuto' which is a type of helmet used by ancient Japanese warriors, including a crest; a suit of traditional samurai armour; a men (mask); boots; and leg armor.

Dimensions (as displayed):
Width: 30 cm
Height: 38 cm
Depth: 44 cm

name: Gogatsu-Ningyo Samurai Armor Set incl. Yoroi and Kabuto #8
description:
Background: In the Edo period (1603-1867), people used to display a set of helmet and armor, weapons and banners outdoors on the 'Tango-no-Sekku' Festival which marks the beginning of summer or the rainy season. Tan means "edge" or "first" and go means "noon". 

Nowadays Gogatsu-Ningyo (doll warrior) are usually displayed on May 5 which has become 'Kodomo no Hi' or Children's day. In contrast to the Hina Festival on March 3 which was and remains an occasion to wish for a girl's safe passage into adulthood, this festival has been developed into an event to wish for a boy's strong growth and bravery.

This handmade Gogatsu Ningyo includes a 'kabuto' which is a type of helmet used by ancient Japanese warriors, including a crest; a suit of traditional samurai armour; a men (mask); boots; leg armor; and a black lacquered box into which the Gogatsu Ningyo can be stored when not displayed.

Dimensions of wooden box: 
(bottom) 340mm x 220mm 
(top) 303mm x 181mm
(height) 236mm

Dimensions of dō (chest armour):
W350mm x L350mm x H150mm

Dimensions of mengu (facial armour):
W60mm x 100mm x H40mm

Dimensions of kabuto (helmet):
W150mm x L140mm x H117mm

Total dimensions with Gogatsu Ningyo (Warrior Doll) placed on top of wooden box:
340mm x 220mm x H520mm

Background: In the Edo period (1603-1867), people used to display a set of helmet and armor, weapons and banners outdoors on the 'Tango-no-Sekku' Festival which marks the beginning of summer or the rainy season. Tan means "edge" or "first" and go means "noon". 

Nowadays Gogatsu-Ningyo (doll warrior) are usually displayed on May 5 which has become 'Kodomo no Hi' or Children's day. In contrast to the Hina Festival on March 3 which was and remains an occasion to wish for a girl's safe passage into adulthood, this festival has been developed into an event to wish for a boy's strong growth and bravery.

This handmade Gogatsu Ningyo includes a 'kabuto' which is a type of helmet used by ancient Japanese warriors, including a crest; a suit of traditional samurai armour; and a black lacquered box into which the Gogatsu Ningyo can be stored when not displayed.

Dimensions:
Width of box: 40.5cm
Height of box: 29cm
Depth of box: 31.5cm
Height of doll + box: 74.5cm

name: Japanese Iaitō Replica Tachi
description:
Background: A tachi (太刀) was a type of Japanese sword worn by the samurai class of feudal Japan. The tachi style of swords preceded the development of the katana. The daitō (long swords) that pre-date the katana average about 78 cm in blade length, larger than the katana average of around 70 cm. Unlike the traditional manner of wearing the katana, the tachi was worn hung from the belt with the cutting-edge down, and was usually used by cavalry. Deviations from the average length of tachi have the prefixes ko- for "short" and ō- for "great or large" attached.

Iaitō (literally meaning mock or imitation sword) is the name given by practitioners of iaidō used for practicing Japanese sword arts. The blade is made of zinc alloy but its blade is not sharpened and is not considered a weapon and export is therefore unrestricted. This replica tachi makes for a beautiful ornament and is popular with cosplayers as well.

tsuka (grip) 25cm
tsuba (guard) 27cm (diameter)
nagasa (blade) 75.5cm
saya (scabbard) 80cm

total length: 105cm
weight: 1300gram

*Stand Sold Separately

name: Japanese Iaitō Replica Daisho (Katana Set) #4
description:
Background: Historically, katana (刀) were one of the traditionally made Japanese swords that were worn by the samurai class of feudal Japan, also commonly referred to as a "samurai sword". The katana is characterized by its distinctive appearance: a curved, slender, single-edged blade with a circular or squared guard and long grip to accommodate two hands.

The katana was often paired with a similar smaller companion sword, such as a wakizashi (脇差) or it could also be worn with the tantō (短刀), a smaller, similarly shaped dagger. The pairing of a katana with a smaller sword is called the daishō (大小).

The etymology of the word daishō (大小) becomes apparent when the terms daitō (大刀), meaning long sword, and shōtō 小刀, meaning short sword, are used; daitō + shōtō = daishō.

Iaitō (literally meaning mock or imitation sword) is the name given by practitioners of iaidō used for practicing Japanese sword arts. The blades are made of zinc alloy but the blades are not sharpened and they are not considered weapons and export is therefore unrestricted. This replica daishō makes for a beautiful ornament and is popular with cosplayers as well.

katana (long sword):
tsuka (grip) 25cm
tsuba (guard) 24.5cm (diameter)
nagasa (blade) 73.5cm
saya (scabbard) 77.5cm
total length: 103cm
weight: 1200gram

wakizashi (shorter sword):
tsuka (grip) 17cm

nagasa (blade) 48cm

total length: 69cm

name: Hagoita #6
description:
Traditional Japanese Hagoita

Background: Hagoita (羽子板) are rectangular wooden paddles, originating in Japan, used to play hanetsuki (a game similar to badminton), but often instead serving a more ornamental purpose. 

These are frequently painted, usually with lacquer, with auspicious symbols, or decorated with complex silk collages. This tradition dates to the 17th century, and although the game itself is now rarely played, crafting decorative hagoita is still commonplace. 

They are generally sold at traditional fairs (hagoita ichi) which are held in December. In Tokyo, they are sold at shrines, especially Asakusa and Furukawa Fudō.

Dimensions: 
Length: 39 cm
Width (at top) 12.5 cm

name: Japanese Sword (katana) Display Stand
description:
katana multiple display stand

Historically, katana (刀) were one of the traditionally made Japanese swords (日本刀 nihontō) that were worn by the samurai class of feudal Japan, also commonly referred to as a "samurai sword". Modern versions of the katana are sometimes made using non-traditional materials and methods.

The katana is characterized by its distinctive appearance: a curved, slender, single-edged blade with a circular or squared guard and long grip to accommodate two hands. It has historically been associated with the samurai of feudal Japan and has become renowned for its sharpness and strength.

The katana was often paired with a similar smaller companion sword, such as a wakizashi (脇差) or it could also be worn with the tantō (短刀), a smaller, similarly shaped dagger. The pairing of a katana with a smaller sword is called the daishō (大小).

The etymology of the word daishō (大小) becomes apparent when the terms daitō (大刀), meaning long sword, and shōtō 小刀, meaning short sword, are used; daitō + shōtō = daishō.

katana (daitō and shōtō) display rack:

Displays 8 swords
Width at bottom: 56cm
Width at top: 43cm
Depth: 24cm
Height: 100cm
Color: black
Parts: 6 + 4 small wedges
Assembly: wedged (no screws)

name: Japanese Sword (tachi) Display Stand
description:
katana display stand

Historically, katana (刀) were one of the traditionally made Japanese swords (日本刀 nihontō) that were worn by the samurai class of feudal Japan, also commonly referred to as a "samurai sword". Modern versions of the katana are sometimes made using non-traditional materials and methods.

The katana is characterized by its distinctive appearance: a curved, slender, single-edged blade with a circular or squared guard and long grip to accommodate two hands. It has historically been associated with the samurai of feudal Japan and has become renowned for its sharpness and strength.

A tachi (太刀) was a type of Japanese sword worn by the samurai class of feudal Japan. The tachi style of swords preceded the development of the katana.

Authentic tachi were forged during the middle ages, before 1596. With a few exceptions katana and tachi can be distinguished from each other if signed, by the location of the signature (mei) on the tang (nakago). In general the mei should be carved into the side of the nakago that would face outward when the sword was worn. Since a tachi was worn cutting edge down, and the katana was worn cutting edge up the mei would be in opposite locations on the nakago of both types of swords.

katana (tachi) display stand:

Displays 1 swords
Width: 30cm
Depth: 21cm
Height: 62.5cm
Color: black
Parts: 2 + 1 wedge
Assembly: wedged (no screws)

The katana is characterized by its distinctive appearance: a curved, slender, single-edged blade with a circular or squared guard and long grip to accommodate two hands. It has historically been associated with the samurai of feudal Japan and has become renowned for its sharpness and strength.

The katana was often paired with a similar smaller companion sword, such as a wakizashi (脇差) or it could also be worn with the tantō (短刀), a smaller, similarly shaped dagger. The pairing of a katana with a smaller sword is called the daishō (大小).

The etymology of the word daishō (大小) becomes apparent when the terms daitō (大刀), meaning long sword, and shōtō 小刀, meaning short sword, are used; daitō + shōtō = daishō.

name: Traditional Japanese Umbrella/Parasol
description:
Background: A wagasa (和傘) is a traditional Japanese umbrella made from paper and bamboo. Wagasa are distinguished from western umbrellas by their large number of ribs (spokes) and their straight rather than rounded shape, resembling cocktail umbrellas. Unlike a standard umbrella, a wagasa is placed with the top of the umbrella facing upwards when not in use.

Dimensions: 
folded length: 66.5cm 
unfolded diameter: 93cm

name: Traditional Japanese Tengu Mask #5
description:
Background: The Tengu are a type of legendary creature found in Japanese folk religion and are also considered a type of Shinto god (kami) or supernatural beings) (yōkai). Although they take their name from a dog-like Chinese demon (Tiangou), the tengu were originally thought to take the forms of birds of prey, and they are traditionally depicted with both human and avian characteristics. The earliest tengu were pictured with beaks, but this feature has often been humanized as an unnaturally long nose, which today is widely considered the tengu's defining characteristic in the popular imagination. Buddhism long held that the tengu were disruptive demons and harbingers of war. Their image gradually softened, however, into one of protective, if still dangerous, spirits of the mountains and forests. Tengu are associated with the ascetic practice known as Shugendō, and they are usually depicted in the distinctive garb of its followers, the yamabushi.

*stand not included

Dimensions: 
W150mm x L205mm x D130mm

Material: Ceramic

name: Traditional Japanese Kagura Mask #4
description:
Background: Kagura is a Japanese word referring to a specific type of Shinto theatrical dance—with roots arguably predating those of Noh. Once strictly a ceremonial art derived from kami'gakari and chinkon, Kagura has evolved in many directions over the span of a millennium. Today it is very much a living tradition, with rituals tied to the rhythms of the agricultural calendar, as well as vibrant Kabuki-esque theatre, thriving primarily in parts of Shimane prefecture, and urban centers such as Hiroshima.

*stand not included

Dimensions: 
W180mm x L210mm x D100mm

Material: Ceramic

name: Traditional Japanese Yamabushi Tengu Mask #3
description:
Background: The Tengu are a type of legendary creature found in Japanese folk religion and are also considered a type of Shinto god (kami) or supernatural beings) (yōkai). Although they take their name from a dog-like Chinese demon (Tiangou), the tengu were originally thought to take the forms of birds of prey, and they are traditionally depicted with both human and avian characteristics. The earliest tengu were pictured with beaks, but this feature has often been humanized as an unnaturally long nose, which today is widely considered the tengu's defining characteristic in the popular imagination. Buddhism long held that the tengu were disruptive demons and harbingers of war. Their image gradually softened, however, into one of protective, if still dangerous, spirits of the mountains and forests. Tengu are associated with the ascetic practice known as Shugendō, and they are usually depicted in the distinctive garb of its followers, the yamabushi.

*stand not included

Dimensions: 
W180mm x L256mm x D200mm

Material: Washi (Japanese rice paper)

name: Traditional Japanese Shikami Mask #2
description:
Background: The shikami is a demon mask with features such as fang-like teeth, furrowed brow and a snarling mouth. This mask displays the ferocious expressions and thereby, the nature of demons. The color of shikami masks represent rage or anger. Teeth and eyes of the shikami mask are painted in metallic gold color.

*stand not included

Dimensions: 
W165mm x L220mm x D90mm

Material: Washi (Japanese rice paper)

name: Traditional Japanese Fox Mask #1
description:
Background: The Kitsune or Japanese Fox is found in many instances of Japanese Folk Lore, with both benevolent and malicious qualities. On the favorable side, the Fox is believed to be the messenger of the God of Rice, while on the darker side, Foxes are said to have the ability to take the shape of humans, and trick and deceive them. The Fox is also said to possess Infinite Vision, an All-Hearing Ear, and the secrets of the souls of others. He is also said to have full knowledge of the Universal Past and Present.

*stand not included

Dimensions: 
W155mm x L270mm x D110mm

Material: Washi (Japanese rice paper)

name: Vintage Gogatsu Ningyo V003
description:
Vintage Gogatsu Ningyo (Traditional Japanese Warrior Doll)

Background: In Japan, the traditional Tango-no-Sekku Festival is held in May to wish for boys’ healthy growth. Families with boys celebrate this day by displaying the Gogatsu Ningyo (warrior doll) display reproduced as art objects, which were once worn by brave warriors. This tradition originated during the Heian Period more than 1200 years ago to ward off evil spirits. Later in the feudal era, this ritual evolved into a ceremony to pray for boys’ fortune and success in wars, and then gradually spread among the common people as a festival for children. 

Dimensions: 
(base) 365mm x 275mm 
(height) 450mm
